Former Candidate Anderson
Discusses Status of Presidency
Finds Past Leaders Have Abused Power
by Lynette Liu
At the 1987 John F. Kennedy
and Robert F. Kennedy Memorial
Lecture on International Affairs
which took place Tuesday, April
7 in Shriver Hall, former
presidential candidate John
Anderson spoke on "The Status
of the Presidency: New Definitions of Power."
The lecture was sponsored by
the Political Science Honor
Society and Student Council.
Anderson, the 1980 Independent
Presidential candidate, thought
the topic was especially timely
because of the upheaval caused by
the Iran arms scandal.
Anderson expressed his disapproval of the way past and present United States presidents have
wielded their power. He cited examples of how presidents have
violated treaties to making covert
arms sales,justifying their actions
to the American public by brandishing the threat of a "red tide."
Examples of abuse of presidential power, he said, have ranged
from Watergate to the War,
Powers Act. In retaliation, Congress has reacted by limitation
acts such as the Arms Export
Control Act and Foreign
Assistance Act.
Anderson reminded voters that
an administration must be constantly monitored, not just
scrutinized once every four years
when election time rolls around.
Ideally, Congress should also act
as a check on the executive
branch.
He said, however, this check
has not always been possible,
citing Congress'not being informed of the sale of arms to Iran and
therefore being powerless to give
a stamp of approval or disap-

proval to the sale.
Anderson does not want a weak
or shackled executive. Instead, he
advocated an accountable one.
The President can make a decision for peace, he said, but Congress must ratify it. He disagreed
with former CIA director
William Casey's opinion that
"there are things Congress
doesn't need to know."
In a tongue-in-cheek manner,
Anderson referred to former CIA
Director Admiral Turner's wish
that better relations be built between the CIA and Congress,
hardly a simple task with the CIA
witholding information from
Congress, he said.
Of course, that accountability
of a president is difficult to
guarantee. Anderson suggested
indoctrinating presidential candidates with "the peril that he
must report to Congress and take

These days you're going to get the

Hair Unlimited. This tiny studio,
tucked away in the basement of a
white-stucco apartment building,
certainly has low overhead, but
your hair looks great once you
climb back to street level. The proprietor, Ellen Gifford, has been
cutting for 12 years and has owned
this' shop for more than half that
time. She has a steady, experienced
hand, and tells the best jokes we've ,

Tenn. May Drug-Test Students
College Press Service—Even as
some athletes began suing to stop
having to take drug tests, a Tennessee state legislator has introduced a bill that would require
anyone who wants t9 atte,nd one
of the state's colleges to be tested
for drug use.
Duke University is the only
other campus in the United States
to have toyed with the idea of
making all students submit to
drug tests.
The idea, which was dropped
at Duke last fall, is not very
popular at the University of
Tennessee.

"The law hasn't passed," said
Don Eastman, assistant to the
university's chancellor, "and
we'd certainly resist it if it did."
"Basically," added Hedy
Weinberg of the American Civil
Liberties Union in Nashville, "it
treats the innocent and guilty
alike. It's patently unconstitutional because it doesn't ask for
'probable cause."
Tennessee State Senator Bill
Richardson, who introduced the
bill, which would bar applicants
who tested positive for drugs
from attending any of Tennessee's twenty-four public cam-

puses, does not agree that his idea
has any constitutional problems.
His bill, he said, "places the
fear of detection out" before
young persons, and thus could
convince then not to use drugs.
Richardson said it is unfair to
test only athletes. "I don't like
singling out athletes." The fairest
law, he added, would "cover
everyone, and not single out any
one group."
A faculty committee at Duke,
however, rejected a similar idea,
judging drug abuse less rampant
among nonathletes than athletes.

universities have sophisticated
computers, he said, and
presumably they might be used to
allow newspaper-to-newspaper
communication.
Karraker said that direct
computer-to-computer linkups
between Western and Soviet college newspapers would be an
historic breakthrough. "Our best
information is that the Soviets
have few microcomputers, keep
access to them highly controlled
and allow little computer communication outside the country,"
he said. "Allowing our college

newspapers to communicate
directly with theirs would indicate
an important shift in Soviet thinking," he continued. "The tests
between ISIS and the Soviet embassy in Ottawa are a very important first step."
In Washington, Alexander
Malyskin, the Soviet Embassy's
senior information officer, said
that Bogdanov's offer extended to
Canadian universities also extends to be U.S. colleges. "This is
something to build bridges between both countries," he said.
"It would be helpful for young
people to discuss different problems, perhaps dealing with
education, sports, public life,
love or family," he continued.
"There are a lot of problems of
common interest. Exchange between student newspapers would
be very useful."

On April 1, 1959, the News-Letter
reported that the Student Council had
voted itself out of existence "to make
way for a 'more representative' form of
student government" —namely no student government at all. After reviewing the debate which dominated last
Wednesday's meeting, we couldn't help
recalling our twenty-eight year old article and wondering if such a move
might not cause an improvement in the
quality of our student government
today.
This week, the item which elicited the
most discussion at Council was, once
again, the upper quad rally and counterprotest held by the Coalition for a Free
South Africa and the College
Republicans on March 18. Specifically, debate centered on the scuffle which
broke out between Scott David Lippe
and a non-student pro-Coalition protester. At its last meeting before Spring
Break, Council analyzed the scuffle in
detail. This week, Council re-analyzed
its earlier analyses. No conclusions
were made.
If by now you've lost track of the
original incident and its "important"
political repercussions, you're not
alone. For the life of us, we're having
trouble following Council's seemingly
aimless discussions on the topic—yet we
..seem to be right in the thick of it all.

(Council members spent a large portion
of their most recent deliberations
discussing the role the News-Letter
played in covering the absurdly protracted debates.)
For the record, we stand by the accuracy of our earlier reports on the scuffle scandal, specifically our account
printed on April 3.
Also for the record, we believe the
entire issue is patently ridiculous.
Whatever the cause of the original
scuffle, one thing is sure—it's none of
Council's business. Fights which break
out on campus, depending on the circumstances, ought to be resolved by existing institutions equipped to handle
them, like Campus Security, the Office
of the Dean of Students, or the
Baltimore City Police Department.
Surely, there are more pressing matters for Council to address in the final
days of the 1986-87 academic year than
the petty problems of attention-seeking
protesters. By casting itself into the
pseudo-judicial role of censurer (or
potential censurer) Council has only attempted to usurp the legitimate authority
of other more appropriate institutions.
In the last weeks of the year, we hope
Council will return to tackle some of the
important issues it has raised in recent
weeks and allow the issue of the scuffle to rest.

Tom in

Frank was sick. Some deadly
viral strain had infected his renal
system. No one knew if he would
survive. I was in Baltimore. It had
to be part of some supernatural
plan. It was my destiny. . . to
take his place. Tom in town.
It was my first day at Hopkins.
A relative newcomer by any standards, I felt like an old hand
already. Maybe that was because
there already was a Tom
McNamara enrolled on the
Baltimore campus. He was a
fake. I knew very well that I was
the real Tom McNamara and this
was my first day: April 8. By
noon I found the crumbled remains of the once-proud Shanty
village on the Hopkins mall. I
wandered through the zoo of
sculptured animals in the flower
garden near where Ike's brother
once ruled proud over the
University. Impressive. Real
nice.
You may be wondering, and
rightly so, what I was doing here
at Hopkins in the first place. I was
,on an East Coast odyssey. A guy
from Minnesota (It's a state near
Minneapolis) out to see the
world. The previous week had
taken me through Boston, New
York, New
Haven and
Washington. After much wandering I finally arrived in the geomagnetic center of the whole East
Coast complex. Baltimore. There
were seals here, and plenty of
them. There was even a big fat
one who wouldn't go in the water
no matter how much we pleaded
with him. I could see his reasoning. A big warship docked nearby, anything could happen. The
harbour was exciting but real
dangerous. I walked around
anyway, in mixed company of
course.
We switched gears and decided to experience the seamier side
of Baltimore. Even Minnesotans
had heard stories about the The
Horse You Came In On Bar. It
was famous. There were lots of
rough and ready sailors down
there. A real tough lot of sea
salts. It was dangerous, real
dangerous. We went in anyway.
Some tough, bearded sailor was
singing old Men At Work tunes.
Sailors like that kind of stuff.
There was even free popcorn.
.Simply unbelievable. People in

Baltimore really live the high life.
It was back to Hopkins and that
dynamic social center on Charles:
Pls. There were pillars of
academia everywhere. Lots of
discussions on chromosomes and
neuron receptors. Those Hoppies
were smart, real smart. I didn't
stand a chance. I resolved to attend a biological engineering
course the next day to make up
for lost time. And for pleasure of
course.
I didn't make it to class the next
morning but I did have a good
reason. I sort of wanted to sleep
some more, besides I wasn't
enrolled anyways. They can't
dock you letter points when
you're not supposed to be there,
not even at Hopkins. I felt pretty
guilty anyway. I decided to make
up for it by touring the campus
very intensely.
It was an amzaing place for a
guy from the Mid-West. After all
this was the city that claimed the
birthplace of Betsy Ross. It was
very colonial. Hopkins was once
a farm and it showed. Charles
Carroll's barn was now a
prestigious drama center. From
hay-filled horse stalls to contemporary theatre; there was nothing
these Hoppies didn't think of.
One could only wonder what

By Jose J. Ivey

Reaping The Whirlwind is an
in-depth study of race relations in
Macon County, Alabama. Spanning more than a century, it takes
the reader from Reconstruction
into the early 1980's, and places
the civil rights movement of the
1960's in a much larger historical
context. There, the author
focuses on two struggles in particular: voting rights and school
desegregation. Through local
documents and detailed interviews, Norell brings the racial
conflict down to the level of the
individual, each with his own
fears and ambitions. Men such as
Booker T. Washington and
George Wallace lose their largerthan-life aura in Norell's hands
and become both understandable
and approachable on a human
level.
There is a value to this work
which goes beyond the history of
Macon County. The struggle
Norell details is a strange one: it
• is economic and political and at
the same time it is neither. Such
is the nature of racial conflict. It
is not enough to say that blacks
are a politically, economically,
and educationally disadvantaged
group, and that by isolating and
addressing these issues their problems will dissipate. There is a
distinct and unavoidable disadvantage to being in the black
minority in this country, which
can only be discussed in the context of racism. This is the
message that Norell, perhaps unconsciously, most clearly states.
The blacks of Macon County
were denied their rights in this
society because they were black,
and for no other reason. This is
the reason why this book and
others like it have a fundamental
importance.
In 1987 many would like to
believe that slavery was long ago,
that racism has been all but
eradicated, that in fact the civil
rights movement of the 1960's
placed blacks on an equal footing
with the majority, eliminating
race as a factor to success. Norell
reminds us that this is simply not
the case. Consider the case of
John Battle, Governor of
Alabama until 1962."'My constant companion during my
boyhood days,' Battle told the
Alabama officials, 'was Cullen
A. Battle, the Confederate
General who in 1870 led Macon
County conservatives in their
violent retrieval of political power
from James Alston and the black
republicans . . . None of you
white citizens and officials of
Alabama believe more strongly
than I do in the segregation of the
races as the right and proper way
of life in the South.'" Keep in
mind that confederate generals
were slave owners, and that Battle's euphemism, "violent
retrieval," was realized as
beatings, arson and murder
against elected black officials.
Then perhaps slavery and its
effects are not that far removed
from the present; but surely, the
ignorance that breeds racism has
been eliminated. The author
recalls that George Wallace succeeded Battle as governor of
Alabama. An infamous opponent

of the civil rights movement, in
his inaugural speech he declared,
"In the name of the greatest people that have ever trod the earth
. . .1 say segregation now!
Segregation tomorrow! Segregation forever!" George Wallace
was governor of Alabama until
last year; still extremely popular,
he retired because of failing
health. Racism is alive and
flourishing. Recent violence in
New York City reminds us that
this is not just a Southern
problem.
Moreover, in the 1980's,
blacks are, if anything, "less
equal" than during the fight for
equality. Norell comments on this

the black community, there was

reader with information. He has
possessed a keen understanding

perhaps because he is a white

condemns nor defends the conservatives. These characters become
quite human and plausible in his

significant contingent of white
liberals who supported the social

their liberal views, and why they
were disenfranchised under the
existing power Structure.

through the 1960's, focusing on
the changes in the power structure
within the black community.
Students, dissatisfied with the
gradualist approach and the
growing distance between the
black middle and lower classes,
rapidly became the new,
"grassroots" leadership of the
black community. Change began
to come more quickly to Macon.
He closes by bringing the reader
up to date on the political and
social changes through 1983. He
brings together a century of
seemingly disjointed events into
a unified and continuous history.
The major weakness of
Norell's book is in his treatment
of the black leaders. While he
discusses them fairly, accurately,
and with considerable detail, they
nonetheless lack the depth and
humanity of his white characters.
He discusses blacks with a certain
detachment, a distance not felt
when he deals with the white
characters. This may be a shortcoming of his research, cases
where black sources may not
have been as open and frank with
him as the white sources. Or
perhaps it is a reflection of the
mind of the author, who is
himself a white southerner and
may not understand the black segment of his long-segregated
society as well as he does the
white. In either case, the flaw is
significant but not disastrous.
Reaping The Whirlwind is a
good place to begin an understanding of the civil rights movement.
It is a balanced, accurate, and important work. In addition, there
are several books available in the
library on Tuskegee Institute,
SNCC. CORE, Dr. Martin
Luther King, Jr., and Malcolm

follow-ups.

A Healthy Lifestyle Even for Hopkins Students
by Kim Juvan
"Sound mind, sound body,"
"You are what you eat.
We're all familiar with these
phrases, but many of us take their
meaning for granted. According
to Linda Rhoades, adult nurse
practitioner at the Student Health
Clinic, college students "can get
away with poor diet/exercise
habits.— For example, if they fall
into a routine of doughnut/coffee
breakfasts or no morning food at
all, they may just get a dragging
feeling until lunchtime. However,
by the time they reach their thirties, "the caffeine and poor diet
habits can manifest themselves as
physical ailments. . . such as
ulcers."
For everyone without special
medical needs, Ms. Rhoades'
dietary advice is very simple: ample portions of the four basic food
groups (meat [2 servings/dayl,
vegetables [4], grains [41, dairy
[4]) on a regular, daily schedule
to provide necessary vitamins and
minerals. And, she adds that
caloric intake should be apportioned with 20%,30%, and 50%
from protein, carbohydrates, and
fat, respectively. Ms. Rhoades
points out that vitamin pills are
inadequate substitutes for natural
sources which are". . . better absorbed and metabolized by the
body."
Ms. Rhoades has observed that
many Hopkins students follow inadequate and irregular diet plans
which can adversely affect their
daily lives. She says the coffee
and doughnut breakfast "is one of
the worst ways to treat your body
in the morning." The "sugar
high — is quickly followed by
hypoglycemia, an abnormal
decrease in blood sugar which
robs the body of energy. Alcohol,
she adds, "provides no vitamins
or minerals but is loaded with
empty calories."
In time, an inadequate diet can
evidence itself in physical appearance and general attitude.
For example, low iron intake
causes anemia because fewer re0

blood cells are available to carry
oxygen; a person looks pale, gets
short of breath when exercising,
and feels generally rundown. A
good diet, insists Ms. Rhoades,
keeps hair and skin healthy and
improves mental acuity for an
overall feeling of well-being.
For weight loss, Ms. Rhoades
advises ignoring fad diets and
sticking rigidly by the regular
plan mentioned previously.
"Weight loss comes with lower
caloric intake . . .and exercise,"
she says, and adds that the Student Health Center can help
students plan a personal
diet/calorie schedule according to
their personal histories. The
schedule's progress would be
monitored every three weeks.
Ms. Rhoades stresses that increased physical activity should
be accompanied by eating more
natural carbohydrates: grains,
fruits, and vegetables. These
foods "add more minerals to the
body.. .to replace sodium and
potassium lost by sweating." She
explains that losing these electrolytes "can cause severe abdominal and leg cramps.— She
also emphasizes that unlike carbohydrates, protein is not
metabolized by the body during
exercise and that training tones
and builds muscle mass. As a
warning, she points out that protein increases fluid intake, which
may overload the kidneys, causing calcium loss.
Like a good diet, exercise provides many benefits for those who
take time for it. Assistant athletic
trainer Joanne McGurney has
become familiar with the exercising habits of Hopkins students
since arriving here last January.
She currently works in the
Athletic Center's Training Room
where she helps take care of intercollegiate athletes, providing
taping or support equipment and
rehabilitation services for injured
athletes. Though the training
room serves mostly intercollegiate athletes, it does administer emergency first-aid to
non-athletes and takes on a few

students referred from the Health
Center.
According to Ms. McGurney,
the most popular fitness activity
for Hopkins students is jogging,
followed closely by swimming
and weight-lifting. She adds,
"There are more females in
weight-lifting than before," and
that weight programs for individuals are set up if desired.
Ms. McGurney emphasizes the
importance for everyone to participate in some sort of regular
exercise program. For those just
beginning, she suggests an alternating jogging/walking program.
"It's easy to keep jogging. . .once you start slowly,"
she explains and points out that
overweight individuals should be
especially wary of overdoing it.
Jogging, if done properly, isn't
dangerous. Ms. McGurney attributes the few injuries she sees,
for example shin-splints and foot
problems, to improper technique.
Jogging should be done on
cushion-backed or grassy surfaces, as opposed to cement
where the shock from pounding
cannot be absorbed. For those
who find running too rigorous,
Ms. McGurney advises walking
as a nearly equal alternative.
Perhaps the best all-around
fitness sport is swimming. The
exercise loosens up muscles all
over the body, without causing
the physical trauma (from pounding) that jogging may involve.
The Athletic Center's Pool is
open at various hours for general
use: weekdays 7 a.m. to 9 a.m.,
11 a.m. to 4 p.m., and 6:30 p.m.
to 10 p.m.; Saturday 12:00 to 8
p.m., and Sunday 1 p.m. to 8
p.m. For those seeking more
competitive activity, many sports
such as tennis, racquetball and
basketball are great for cardiovascular fitness.
Ms. McGurney stresses that
people should have a regular time
alloted in their schedules for
working out. Those who despise
exercising now "may find it
habit-forming." As a personal
note, she remarks, "I used to

Ilene Jacobs

for a dail work out. The track around Homevmod Field is just part of
the athletic facilities that Hopkins provides.

despise running, but now I feel
really uncomfortable if I miss it."
Cardio-vascular activities, such
as jogging 3 miles or swimming
an hour can be done daily; toning exercises like weight-lifting
or competitive sports where
tedium may develop are better on
an every-other-day basis. The
best time to exercise is a while
after eating, thereby increasing
metabolism and burning off

An extremely important but

that it is an effective stress

test. . .from worrying. Even
though you may have to face studying again. . .exercising gives
you a feeling of accomplishment." Self-improvement comes
from both building physically and

The best overall picture' of

and regular exercise. Without exercise, the tone and size of a muscle declines, whereas a diet of
milkshakes and burgers cannot be

spent preparing for a three-course
meal and regular swimming or
racquetball an investment in mental sharpness as well.

Women in Science: They Can Make a Difference
by Ely Brown
Science and medicine for the
better part of history have been
a man's realm, but now things are
beginning to change. To what extent have women influenced
medicine up until now? How can
they alter it in the future? These
questions and others were the
focal point for the fourth lecture
in the series "The Public Interest
in Science." Two female scientists were the main speakers for
the evening: Elizabeth Fee of the
Johns Hopkins University School
of Hygiene and Public Health,
and Ruth Hubbard from Harvard
University.
Today women do occupy positions in all levels of science, but
in the higher, more dominant stations it is the men who still
dominate. In the lab, women are
researchers, technicians, and

secretaries, but rarely do they
head the lab itself. In the medical
field, many women have become
physicians, but once again men
are in the majority. Fee pointed
out a very important factor concerning this inequality. In the
health care profession, women
occupy a majority of the positions
available, even if they are not the
powerful ones. Dieticians,
nurses, right down to candy
stripers are often women, and
these people are the ones who
directly care for the patient on a
personal level. As Fee sees it, this
is a main problem for the medical
profession. She believes that
physicians, mostly men, "know
about the body," while the
others, mostly women, "care for
it." Medicine should not be split
between the two, but rather a
combination of both.
This is where women came in.

Fee cited one male physician who
believed that to improve medicine
today they would have to
"change the sex and priorities of
the system as a whole." "Body
engineering" is not the wave of
the future in Fee's eyes. It is the
treatment of the body and soul of
the patient as one entity. Today
in general, women work fewer
hours, receive less pay, participate less in private practice,
are more involved with the patient and his needs, and basically
are open to the voice of the life
work as opposed to that of
medicine." These qualities are
what is needed to "reintegrate the
patient into the medical encounter.•'
With more women in the
system, it would be possible to involve medicine more directly
with social problems. For instance, rather than treating only

the injuries of a battered wife, it
would help fight the cause of the
problem, the violent husband.
To Hubbard, more feminist
women in science would provide
"a different way of looking at
nature." Because "science is
knowledge about nature for use"
a new outlook on the world would
alter science. Hubbard, a feminist
herself, believes that women
would use science for more
humane purposes rather than for
"profit, domination, or warfare.—
She pointed to the opinion that
men are very objective while
women are more subjective. She
does not see this as a problem for
women, but rather as an enhancement.
She
referred
to
primatology, the study of
primates, where there are many
prominent women in the field.
Female primatologists saw many

additional and different items in
their study of research data than
males did. They did not create
different "stories" from the
data, but rather elaborated on
them. In Hubbard's point of
view, a similar one to Fee's,
women have the ability to look at
a part and see how it relates to the
whole.
In conclusion, what Fee and
Hubbard were stressing was that
women have a significant contribution to make to science and
medicine. It may not be better
that what exists today, but it is
different and more encompassing. The last lecture of the series
will be held on April 15 at 8 p.m.
in Mudd Lecture Hall, and the
topic will be "Science and Dissent in the Soviet Union."

Lady Laxers Take First In MAC West Division
by Patti Ordonez and Laura
Perlinn
Last Tuesday, April 7th, the
Johns Hopkins women's lacrosse
team made lacrosse history by
beating Gettysburg for the first
time ever. The 13-10 victory put
JHU at the top of the West division of the Middle Atlantic
Conference.
The Lady Laxers began the
match unsure of themselves, as
they were coming off of two
MAC defeats last week-a 7-14
loss to last year's MAC champions and NCAA quarterfinalists,
Haverford, and an agonizing
11-12 loss to Franklin and Marshall. The loss to Franklin and
Marshall had especially upset the
team, for they lost the game in the
last 90 seconds after having had
a 6-1 lead in the first half.

However, the Lady Jays came
through to triumph over Gettysburg in the most crucial MAC
game on their schedule. Coaches
Katie Glose and Jeanette Ireland
agreed that the determining factor was "teamwork all over the
field."
The Gettysburg victory was
important not only for team
morale, but also for determining
whether Hopkins will play in the
MAC Championship. If the Lady
Jays can beat Western Maryland
on April 14 and Dickinson on
April 16, the two remaining
Western division games left on
their schedule, Hopkins would
then claim first place in their division and advance to the championship, held on Saturday, May
2. Head Coach Sally Anderson is
also aiming for an invitation to
the NCAA tournament, which is

possible if Hopkins wins the rest
of their games.
Anderson credits the superior
goalkeeping of Laura Porter and
Jackie Fatula as one reason for
the marked improvement in this
year's team. (Last year's team
had a humiliating 5-24 fall to Gettysburg.) Despite their relative inexperience in lacrosse, both
goalkeepers are averaging 50 percent in saves, one of the many
statistics up from last year. According to Coach Anderson,"We
are much stronger than last year,
On the field, Erika Feller has
been the fulcrum of the defense
at cover point. She has been very
consistent and very strong. Kacie
White has also been a big asset to
the defense. She plays a very persistent defensive wing. She has
speed and works hard." Offensively, the high scorers are Alice

Collins, who is averaging almost
five goals per game; and captain
Heather Klink, who leads the
team in assists with 20.
The win over Gettysburg raised the Lady Laxers' record to 4
wins and 2 losses. Victories
before spring break included a
15-1 Goucher smear, a 16-2
thrashing of Hood College, and
a 20-4 annihilation of MAC opponent Washington College. The
squad also did very well in their
pre-season scrimmages and at
their opening tournament at

Hollands College, in which
Hopkins won 7 of their 8 games
against other teams in the South
Region.
After facing Notre Dame on
Thursday, April 9, the team then
travels to Widener on Saturday
and Western Maryland on Tuesday. The critical game against
Dickinson will be played at
Homewood on Thursday at 6
p.m. The Lady Laxers are determined to continue their winning
ways.

Tenn. May Drug-Test Students
College Press Service—Even as
some athletes began suing to stop
having to take drug tests, a Tennessee state legislator has introduced a bill that would require
anyone who wants t9 atte,nd one
of the state's colleges to be tested
for drug use.
Duke University is the only
other campus in the United States
to have toyed with the idea of
making all students submit to
drug tests.
The idea, which was dropped
at Duke last fall, is not very
popular at the University of
Tennessee.

"The law hasn't passed," said
Don Eastman, assistant to the
university's chancellor, "and
we'd certainly resist it if it did."
"Basically," added Hedy
Weinberg of the American Civil
Liberties Union in Nashville, "it
treats the innocent and guilty
alike. It's patently unconstitutional because it doesn't ask for
'probable cause."
Tennessee State Senator Bill
Richardson, who introduced the
bill, which would bar applicants
who tested positive for drugs
from attending any of Tennessee's twenty-four public cam-

puses, does not agree that his idea
has any constitutional problems.

Tom in

Frank was sick. Some deadly
viral strain had infected his renal
system. No one knew if he would
survive. I was in Baltimore. It had
to be part of some supernatural
plan. It was my destiny. . . to
take his place. Tom in town.
It was my first day at Hopkins.
A relative newcomer by any standards, I felt like an old hand
already. Maybe that was because
there already was a Tom
McNamara enrolled on the
Baltimore campus. He was a
fake. I knew very well that I was
the real Tom McNamara and this
was my first day: April 8. By
noon I found the crumbled remains of the once-proud Shanty
village on the Hopkins mall. I
wandered through the zoo of
sculptured animals in the flower
garden near where Ike's brother
once ruled proud over the
University. Impressive. Real
nice.
You may be wondering, and
rightly so, what I was doing here
at Hopkins in the first place. I was
,on an East Coast odyssey. A guy
from Minnesota (It's a state near
Minneapolis) out to see the
world. The previous week had
taken me through Boston, New
York, New
Haven and
Washington. After much wandering I finally arrived in the geomagnetic center of the whole East
Coast complex. Baltimore. There
were seals here, and plenty of
them. There was even a big fat
one who wouldn't go in the water
no matter how much we pleaded
with him. I could see his reasoning. A big warship docked nearby, anything could happen. The
harbour was exciting but real
dangerous. I walked around
anyway, in mixed company of
course.
We switched gears and decided to experience the seamier side
of Baltimore. Even Minnesotans
had heard stories about the The
Horse You Came In On Bar. It
was famous. There were lots of
rough and ready sailors down
there. A real tough lot of sea
salts. It was dangerous, real
dangerous. We went in anyway.
Some tough, bearded sailor was
singing old Men At Work tunes.
Sailors like that kind of stuff.
There was even free popcorn.
.Simply unbelievable. People in

Baltimore really live the high life.
It was back to Hopkins and that
dynamic social center on Charles:
Pls. There were pillars of
academia everywhere. Lots of
discussions on chromosomes and
neuron receptors. Those Hoppies
were smart, real smart. I didn't
stand a chance. I resolved to attend a biological engineering
course the next day to make up
for lost time. And for pleasure of
course.
I didn't make it to class the next
morning but I did have a good
reason. I sort of wanted to sleep
some more, besides I wasn't
enrolled anyways. They can't
dock you letter points when
you're not supposed to be there,
not even at Hopkins. I felt pretty
guilty anyway. I decided to make
up for it by touring the campus
very intensely.
It was an amzaing place for a
guy from the Mid-West. After all
this was the city that claimed the
birthplace of Betsy Ross. It was
very colonial. Hopkins was once
a farm and it showed. Charles
Carroll's barn was now a
prestigious drama center. From
hay-filled horse stalls to contemporary theatre; there was nothing
these Hoppies didn't think of.
One could only wonder what
would happen to the old Ham
Radio building. A hockey rink or
a hospital, the possibilities were
endless here at Hopkins. Gilman
Hall was home to a quaint cafe,
a Post Office which mailed letters
all over the known world and a
plethora of financial institutions.
It was a multi-purpose kind of
place.
The afternoon found Blue Jays
all over campus playing ball with
funny little netted sticks. It looked fun, maybe just a little too fun.
I decided on a little racquetball instead. Some of these Hoppies
were really athletic types. I decided to lose on purpose and blame
those funny squash courts.
The day was drawing to a
close. It was my first day at the
big JHU. I retired to a typewriter
at the old Gatehouse now housing the Hopkins News-Letter.
Lots of history there. Who knows
what those crazy gatekeepers used to do in the sev&teenth century. But the evening was yet
young. The possibilities were
endless in Hoppieland.

Norell Narration of Racism

By Jose J. Ivey

Reaping The Whirlwind is an
in-depth study of race relations in
Macon County, Alabama. Spanning more than a century, it takes
the reader from Reconstruction
into the early 1980's, and places
the civil rights movement of the
1960's in a much larger historical
context. There, the author
focuses on two struggles in particular: voting rights and school
desegregation. Through local
documents and detailed interviews, Norell brings the racial
conflict down to the level of the
individual, each with his own
fears and ambitions. Men such as
Booker T. Washington and
George Wallace lose their largerthan-life aura in Norell's hands
and become both understandable
and approachable on a human
level.
There is a value to this work
which goes beyond the history of
Macon County. The struggle
Norell details is a strange one: it
• is economic and political and at
the same time it is neither. Such
is the nature of racial conflict. It
is not enough to say that blacks
are a politically, economically,
and educationally disadvantaged
group, and that by isolating and
addressing these issues their problems will dissipate. There is a
distinct and unavoidable disadvantage to being in the black
minority in this country, which
can only be discussed in the context of racism. This is the
message that Norell, perhaps unconsciously, most clearly states.
The blacks of Macon County
were denied their rights in this
society because they were black,
and for no other reason. This is
the reason why this book and
others like it have a fundamental
importance.
In 1987 many would like to
believe that slavery was long ago,
that racism has been all but
eradicated, that in fact the civil
rights movement of the 1960's
placed blacks on an equal footing
with the majority, eliminating
race as a factor to success. Norell
reminds us that this is simply not
the case. Consider the case of
John Battle, Governor of
Alabama until 1962."'My constant companion during my
boyhood days,' Battle told the
Alabama officials, 'was Cullen
A. Battle, the Confederate
General who in 1870 led Macon
County conservatives in their
violent retrieval of political power
from James Alston and the black
republicans . . . None of you
white citizens and officials of
Alabama believe more strongly
than I do in the segregation of the
races as the right and proper way
of life in the South.'" Keep in
mind that confederate generals
were slave owners, and that Battle's euphemism, "violent
retrieval," was realized as
beatings, arson and murder
against elected black officials.
Then perhaps slavery and its
effects are not that far removed
from the present; but surely, the
ignorance that breeds racism has
been eliminated. The author
recalls that George Wallace succeeded Battle as governor of
Alabama. An infamous opponent

of the civil rights movement, in
his inaugural speech he declared,
"In the name of the greatest people that have ever trod the earth
. . .1 say segregation now!
Segregation tomorrow! Segregation forever!" George Wallace
was governor of Alabama until
last year; still extremely popular,
he retired because of failing
health. Racism is alive and
flourishing. Recent violence in
New York City reminds us that
this is not just a Southern
problem.
Moreover, in the 1980's,
blacks are, if anything, "less
equal" than during the fight for
equality. Norell comments on this
in his conclusion. "Conservatives

authority as a result of the rapid
expansion ot federal and state
power in the 1950's and 60's.
Decisions about education,
welfare, criminal justice, and
educational development in
Macon County were more likely
to be made outside the county
than within it. Poor blacks could
hardly influence those more
remote governments . . .Failures
of interracial cooperation were,
of course, also a legacy of
segregation. Most citizens, black
and white, were simply unable to
overcome in a few years the
generations of racial alienation
and hatred that Macon Countians
had experienced."
Today this nation is faced with

too painful lessons of the past. Attempting to move forward by
forgetting the past is the path of
fools. Works such as Reaping The
Whirlwind are an important
beginning in the understanding of
race relations.
Why was Macon County
chosen for such a detailed work
on racial conflict? With a population of about 8,000 by 1960
spread over three towns and huge
expanses of farmland, it would
not at first seem to be at the
forefront of anything. Yet there
are several important things to
consider when looking at Macon
County. First, blacks had been in
the majority since the beginning
of the 19th century. Second,
Macon is in Alabama, a key
power in the Confederate States
of America, and under the leadership of Gov. George Wallace, a
relentless opponent of the federal
government and the civil rights
movement. To quote Norell,
" . . Macon County can best be
understood in the context of
evolving white anxieties. In the
1850's many white Alabamians

Norell's treatment of the white
community is perhaps the
strongest part of the work. Unlike
the black community, there was
a myriad of white politicians,
businessmen, and prominent
citizens opposed to the social
changes being sought, and the
author includes almost all of
them. Norell was skillfully able
to emphasize the most important
of them, such as Judge William
Varner, and Governors Battle and
Wallace, without diminishing the
contributions of the lesser
characters, or overwhelming the
reader with information. He has
possessed a keen understanding
of the southern white society,
perhaps because he is a white
southerner himself, and neither
condemns nor defends the conservatives. These characters become
quite human and plausible in his
hands. There was also a small but
significant contingent of white
liberals who supported the social
changes. Norell adds uncustomary depth to his treatment
of them by detailing the importance of their backgrounds to
their liberal views, and why they
were disenfranchised under the
existing power Structure.
The book moves quickly
through the 1960's, focusing on
the changes in the power structure
within the black community.
Students, dissatisfied with the
gradualist approach and the
growing distance between the
black middle and lower classes,
rapidly became the new,
"grassroots" leadership of the
black community. Change began
to come more quickly to Macon.
He closes by bringing the reader
up to date on the political and
social changes through 1983. He
brings together a century of
seemingly disjointed events into
a unified and continuous history.
The major weakness of
Norell's book is in his treatment
of the black leaders. While he
discusses them fairly, accurately,
and with considerable detail, they
nonetheless lack the depth and
humanity of his white characters.
He discusses blacks with a certain
detachment, a distance not felt
when he deals with the white
characters. This may be a shortcoming of his research, cases
where black sources may not
have been as open and frank with
him as the white sources. Or
perhaps it is a reflection of the
mind of the author, who is
himself a white southerner and
may not understand the black segment of his long-segregated
society as well as he does the
white. In either case, the flaw is
significant but not disastrous.
Reaping The Whirlwind is a
good place to begin an understanding of the civil rights movement.
It is a balanced, accurate, and important work. In addition, there
are several books available in the
library on Tuskegee Institute,
SNCC. CORE, Dr. Martin
Luther King, Jr., and Malcolm
X, which would make excellent
follow-ups.

A Healthy Lifestyle Even for Hopkins Students
by Kim Juvan
"Sound mind, sound body,"
"You are what you eat.
We're all familiar with these
phrases, but many of us take their
meaning for granted. According
to Linda Rhoades, adult nurse
practitioner at the Student Health
Clinic, college students "can get
away with poor diet/exercise
habits.— For example, if they fall
into a routine of doughnut/coffee
breakfasts or no morning food at
all, they may just get a dragging
feeling until lunchtime. However,
by the time they reach their thirties, "the caffeine and poor diet
habits can manifest themselves as
physical ailments. . . such as
ulcers."
For everyone without special
medical needs, Ms. Rhoades'
dietary advice is very simple: ample portions of the four basic food
groups (meat [2 servings/dayl,
vegetables [4], grains [41, dairy
[4]) on a regular, daily schedule
to provide necessary vitamins and
minerals. And, she adds that
caloric intake should be apportioned with 20%,30%, and 50%
from protein, carbohydrates, and
fat, respectively. Ms. Rhoades
points out that vitamin pills are
inadequate substitutes for natural
sources which are". . . better absorbed and metabolized by the
body."
Ms. Rhoades has observed that
many Hopkins students follow inadequate and irregular diet plans
which can adversely affect their
daily lives. She says the coffee
and doughnut breakfast "is one of
the worst ways to treat your body
in the morning." The "sugar
high — is quickly followed by
hypoglycemia, an abnormal
decrease in blood sugar which
robs the body of energy. Alcohol,
she adds, "provides no vitamins
or minerals but is loaded with
empty calories."
In time, an inadequate diet can
evidence itself in physical appearance and general attitude.
For example, low iron intake
causes anemia because fewer re0

blood cells are available to carry
oxygen; a person looks pale, gets
short of breath when exercising,
and feels generally rundown. A
good diet, insists Ms. Rhoades,
keeps hair and skin healthy and
improves mental acuity for an
overall feeling of well-being.
For weight loss, Ms. Rhoades
advises ignoring fad diets and
sticking rigidly by the regular
plan mentioned previously.
"Weight loss comes with lower
caloric intake . . .and exercise,"
she says, and adds that the Student Health Center can help
students plan a personal
diet/calorie schedule according to
their personal histories. The
schedule's progress would be
monitored every three weeks.
Ms. Rhoades stresses that increased physical activity should
be accompanied by eating more
natural carbohydrates: grains,
fruits, and vegetables. These
foods "add more minerals to the
body.. .to replace sodium and
potassium lost by sweating." She
explains that losing these electrolytes "can cause severe abdominal and leg cramps.— She
also emphasizes that unlike carbohydrates, protein is not
metabolized by the body during
exercise and that training tones
and builds muscle mass. As a
warning, she points out that protein increases fluid intake, which
may overload the kidneys, causing calcium loss.
Like a good diet, exercise provides many benefits for those who
take time for it. Assistant athletic
trainer Joanne McGurney has
become familiar with the exercising habits of Hopkins students
since arriving here last January.
She currently works in the
Athletic Center's Training Room
where she helps take care of intercollegiate athletes, providing
taping or support equipment and
rehabilitation services for injured
athletes. Though the training
room serves mostly intercollegiate athletes, it does administer emergency first-aid to
non-athletes and takes on a few

students referred from the Health
Center.
According to Ms. McGurney,
the most popular fitness activity
for Hopkins students is jogging,
followed closely by swimming
and weight-lifting. She adds,
"There are more females in
weight-lifting than before," and
that weight programs for individuals are set up if desired.
Ms. McGurney emphasizes the
importance for everyone to participate in some sort of regular
exercise program. For those just
beginning, she suggests an alternating jogging/walking program.
"It's easy to keep jogging. . .once you start slowly,"
she explains and points out that
overweight individuals should be
especially wary of overdoing it.

Women in Science: They Can Make a Difference
by Ely Brown
Science and medicine for the
better part of history have been
a man's realm, but now things are
beginning to change. To what extent have women influenced
medicine up until now? How can
they alter it in the future? These
questions and others were the
focal point for the fourth lecture
in the series "The Public Interest
in Science." Two female scientists were the main speakers for
the evening: Elizabeth Fee of the
Johns Hopkins University School
of Hygiene and Public Health,
and Ruth Hubbard from Harvard
University.
Today women do occupy positions in all levels of science, but
in the higher, more dominant stations it is the men who still
dominate. In the lab, women are
researchers, technicians, and

secretaries, but rarely do they
head the lab itself. In the medical
field, many women have become
physicians, but once again men
are in the majority. Fee pointed
out a very important factor concerning this inequality. In the
health care profession, women
occupy a majority of the positions
available, even if they are not the
powerful ones. Dieticians,
nurses, right down to candy
stripers are often women, and
these people are the ones who
directly care for the patient on a
personal level. As Fee sees it, this
is a main problem for the medical
profession. She believes that
physicians, mostly men, "know
about the body," while the
others, mostly women, "care for
it." Medicine should not be split
between the two, but rather a
combination of both.
This is where women came in.

Fee cited one male physician who
believed that to improve medicine
today they would have to
"change the sex and priorities of
the system as a whole." "Body
engineering" is not the wave of
the future in Fee's eyes. It is the
treatment of the body and soul of
the patient as one entity. Today
in general, women work fewer
hours, receive less pay, participate less in private practice,
are more involved with the patient and his needs, and basically
are open to the voice of the life
work as opposed to that of
medicine." These qualities are
what is needed to "reintegrate the
patient into the medical encounter.•'
With more women in the
system, it would be possible to involve medicine more directly
with social problems. For instance, rather than treating only

the injuries of a battered wife, it
would help fight the cause of the
problem, the violent husband.
To Hubbard, more feminist
women in science would provide
"a different way of looking at
nature." Because "science is
knowledge about nature for use"
a new outlook on the world would
alter science. Hubbard, a feminist
herself, believes that women
would use science for more
humane purposes rather than for
"profit, domination, or warfare.—
She pointed to the opinion that
men are very objective while
women are more subjective. She
does not see this as a problem for
women, but rather as an enhancement.
She
referred
to
primatology, the study of
primates, where there are many
prominent women in the field.
Female primatologists saw many

additional and different items in
their study of research data than
males did. They did not create
different "stories" from the
data, but rather elaborated on
them. In Hubbard's point of
view, a similar one to Fee's,
women have the ability to look at
a part and see how it relates to the
whole.
In conclusion, what Fee and
Hubbard were stressing was that
women have a significant contribution to make to science and
medicine. It may not be better
that what exists today, but it is
different and more encompassing. The last lecture of the series
will be held on April 15 at 8 p.m.
in Mudd Lecture Hall, and the
topic will be "Science and Dissent in the Soviet Union."
